post.message:
Why not just compute the probability of each theory being right, conditional on the evidence? What is your prior information?

Have you read Probability Theory, The Logic of Science, by E. T. Jaynes? It might help you out.
http://www.amazon.com/Probabil...

This is a free online version:
http://omega.albany.edu:8008/JaynesBook.html

The probability of each theory being right conditional on the observations is the likelihood. This probability is higher for a model with more parameters.

Typical approaches in this field tend to introduce a penalty for extra parameters, such as AIC (well, it's actually a correction of the bias in maximum likelihood estimation, but looks like a penalty). I show these approaches are not valid in this situation. By generating the distribution of possible outcomes by simulating under each model, it's possible to tell by how much the richer model tends to do better by overfitting (that is, when the data comes from the simpler model).

Does that make sense?
It was Rick, not Phil.
So it was! Not enough coffee. Thanks
Analysis now continues on the next day (originally continued posting under this entry this morning, then moved to its own entry). http://www.carlboettiger.info/...
Hey can I copy and paste this post on my web site? What references must I give? You might give this info for other people too.

Certainly. Just cite me, Carl Boettiger, as the source and possibly link back to this post. All content on this site is licensed under a creative commons attribution share-alike license. Click on the cc icon in the bottom right corner of the page for more information.

Carl-- You rock!!
This is ever so much clearer than my notes.
Thanks a million,
Mau
I have just moved the commenting system for this site to Disqus. This is a trail post.
Lab notebooks now support Disqus commenting.

As you say, in a way one might expect it to be easier to keep an Open Notebook as a theorist since your workflows are already on a computer. But I think your other point that you aren't taught to keep a notebook in your field is a bigger issue. As bench chemists we are (or should be) taught how to keep a good notebook - often for patent documentation purposes. It is also easy to draw a line as to what to record - if you did it in the lab just record it. This usually is not a great burden because of the time it takes to process things physically in a lab doesn't result in large amounts of data. But for computational work, the burden of recording everything done on a computer can be immense. We faced that when doing docking studies. Ultimately the acid test is: did you record enough information that someone outside of your group can figure out what you did? (no insider information ideal) This is why I think doing the session with you will be very informative - we'll get to discuss how much information is enough for both wet and computational work.
See also the new post by Tim Vines, Mol Eco managing editor, discussing potential concerns and answers for data archiving: http://tomato.biol.trinity.edu...
Request feature: Make flickr discription actually link directly to code.

Wondering if this will work as a platform track goals for code development, bugs, and progress. alternatives include using uservoice (only one free forum) or ideatorrent (needs separate hosting). Github wiki also possible, but isn't really a bug tracker.
Ah, nevermind, github has an issues tracker as well now, much better. Moving the requested items into the github issues list for the socialR package

" - Yes, the program was built in hope that would happen in each room....and we also try to do it at the scale of years - one year's conversations are a starting point for next year's.

Another huge thing that can determine species ranges is the occurrence of OTHER species, which are often human driven in some way or another. So no, I don't think this result about humans being as, if not more, important than climate is restricted to big mammals and crops.
Wow, great collection of other posts on the Science Online 2011 conference here: http://scio11.wikispaces.com/B...

Thinking a bit more about Liam's MCMC of diversification rates in comparison to Jon's RJMCMC, posted thoughts here: http://phytools.blogspot.com/2... I believe the primary difference is that Luke and Jon infers transition points, whereas Liam postulates a transition model. Comparisons of the inferences gained from each would be interesting.
Have you considered requesting Drake's microcosm data for this?: http://www.nature.com/nature/j...
Yes indeed, would be great to have copies of that data to analyze as well. Didn't start there since the climate data is already openly accessible.

Let X_1 ... X_k be the states at the tips, and let X_0 be the root. If we don't observe X_0, and want a likelihood function, we can either treat it as a parameter to estimate, or put a distribution on it.

In the BM case there is no obvious distribution to use, but it turns out that if we let Y_i = X_i - X_0, then (Y_1, ... Y_k) are jointly Gaussian and indepenent of X_0. This happens because, roughly speaking, the mean of each of the X_i, given X_0 is equal to X_0, and the variances only depend on the lengths of the intervening branches. So if we treat X_0 as a random quantity, we find its distribution doesn't enter into the likelihood for Y, and if we treat it as a parameter, we find its value does not affect the distribution of Y.

In the OU case, it is no longer so simple, since the means depend on X_0 in a nonlinear way. If we treat X_0 as a random quantity, then the distribution of X_1, .. X_k is a mixture of Gaussian distributions. Suppose we put a distribution m() on X_0. Then the likelihood would be
L = \int_x L_0(x,X_1,X_2, ... X_k) m(x) dx ,
and taking the log of this isn't particularly nice. One justification of ``set X_0 = theta'' might be that we do something like a saddle point approximation of this integral, e.g. replace the integrand with its maximum value -- except in this case, with its value at the point where m(x) is maximum.

However, it's not clear to me why we can't do the equivalent of the BM case for the OU model: The natural distribution to put on X_0 is Gaussian, in which case (X_0, ... X_k) is jointly Gaussian. Note that E[X_i] = theta, for every i, and that cov(X_i,X_j) = V_ij = sigma^2 e^(- alpha T), where T is the time in the tree from i to j (including i or j = 0). Now let Z_0 = X_0 and diagonalize so that Z_1, ... Z_k are uncorrelated to Z_0. This is possible -- one just has to find vectors z such that (1,0,...,0)^T V z = 0 -- and uncorrelated Gaussians are independent. Note that this is different to what Carl has, since that is written as if X_0 was a parameter. I must be missing something?

Great post! I think the question you are asking is a fundamental one. You could turn it on its head, and instead of asking a normative question, i.e. how can open science foster more collaborations, rather ask a practical one, i.e. how better forms of collaboration can lead to more open science? The majority of scientists, as your post implies, don't want everything to be open. And this leads to the kinds of issues in collaborations you described. This does not mean, however, that they are opposed to sharing, rather that they want to share their data when and with whom they want.

You could argue, and in fact I have argued http://www.axiope.com/electron..., that enabling better means of controlled sharing may, somewhat ironically, prove to be the most powerful stimulus to openness.
Thanks for sharing, Carl. What is the socialR package you mention in your post?

Hi Karthik, socialR is an R package I use to wrap up several social tools (flickr, github, twitter) to make it easier for me to track and reproduce my work. You can see it on github here: https://github.com/cboettig/so..., and I describe the package in an earlier post: http://www.carlboettiger.info/...

Thanks Carl. This looks pretty useful. I have previously used twitteR to DM myself updates from inside long simulations running on a high performance cluster. I don't use Flickr for work but I will try out socialR.

I think the move to OAuth broke twitteR, so I call an external twitter command-line script. My goal with the package was to have a database of every figure I create in R with a link to the code that created it, organized by tags, date, etc. socialR is really just a wrapper to some command-line clients so I can do that with a single R plot command from a server, etc, so it won't work out of the box, but if you install the command-line programs (git, flickr_upload, etc) it'll work. For another take on this idea, check out: http://www.stanford.edu/~gavis...

Hi,

You may or may not have found the link to Didelot et al 2011 "Likelihood-free estimation of model evidence" on Christian Robert’s blog. (Disclaimer: I'm one of the authors). We showed some similar things to Robert et al, but additionally we showed that there is an easy way to generate sufficient statistics for the model choice problem (in the exponential family of course).

We continue to have a more positive view of the possibilities of ABC than do Robrt et al!

Dan

Link:
http://ba.stat.cmu.edu/journal...

Hi Dan,

Thanks much for drawing my attention to this paper, I had glanced over the abstract but did not realize that you also treat the Grelaud 2009 case and address the very same issue about sufficiency between models (your equation 16). Your solution to this is to consider a model M in which both M1 and M2 are nested, and find sufficient statistics for M (eq 18?) Would it be fair to describe this as a method for finding sufficient statistics for model comparison by Bayes factors?

-Carl

Hi Carl,

Yes, your description is exactly right. Unfortunately, the proof we use only saves you if you have actually sufficient statistics, which is only practical in the exponential family. However, its my feeling that "approximately sufficiency" can be show to lead to "approximately correct Bayes factors" - but I don't think this is shown yet.

Dan

PS Apologies for mis-spelling Robert....
TreEvo package installs fine from RForge for me. looking forward to some running examples.
Googling for information of ROAuth and twitteR and, of course, the third thing that pops up is this two-hour old post. C'mon Carl, figured it out yet?
Got it working using Jeff Gentry's wonderful documentation. I'll do a write-up of my process later tonight.
Nice, look forward to seeing it.

Jeff set me straight on my liboauth install: Ubuntu hadn't added the libraries to my LD_LIBRARY_PATH. Doing:

Thanks for your comments Carl. A few clarifications and reactions:

1. I didn't, and wouldn't, claim that there's any risk of new data collection ceasing, or a risk that we'll all end up repeatedly mining the same few existing datasets. I'd like to see ecologists use old data in all--and only--those cases where the old data can address the question of interest. The challenge is that, as we increasingly emphasize mining of old data, because we obviously want to use it whenever its appropriate, we're also at increasing risk of using it when it would be better to collect new data, or focus on different questions that can only be addressed with new data.

2. My remark that a lot of ecological datasets are easily handled in standard software like R and Excel wasn't a comment about how often we look back at existing data, or how easy it now is to do so using modern software tools. I was questioning how useful NCEAS' ecoinformatics initiatives have proven to the broad field of ecology.

3. I agree that we're not yet as good as we need to be about curating old data, compiling metadata, etc.

4. The data that we're increasingly flooded with is mostly *certain kinds* of data. Gene sequence data, remotely sensed data, and data from networks of environmental monitoring stations, for instance. We are not flooded with, say, data from field experiments, or multigenerational pedigree and phenotypic trait data such as the Grants have collected on Darwin's finches, or multi-decadal population dynamic time series, etc. Increasing availability of certain kinds of data naturally and rightly encourages us to find ways to use those kinds of data (and also to collect more of them, because those are the sorts of data that 'modern' ecologists collect). My remarks were meant to highlight that this kind of data-driven approach, valuable as it is, also has drawbacks. After all, there's no law of the universe that ensures that technical advances will always ease collection of the kinds of data we'd most like to have. Ecology is hard, and so ecologists are always on the lookout for ways to make it easier--which sometimes leads to us taking blind alleys that look like shortcuts, or settling for second best. Sometimes, big advances come from first deciding what question we'd most like answered, and only then looking to see what sorts of data are available. And if *exactly* the right kind of data aren't available, we don't make do with whatever 'second best' data we've got, we instead suck it up and invest whatever time, money, and effort is necessary to obtain *exactly* the right data. Dave Tilman's Biodiversity I and II experiments at Cedar Creek are just one recent example which comes to mind.

Hi Jeremy,

Thanks for your reply, I think it's dead-on, so sorry if I misconstrued anything.  I think our discussion hits on some interesting challenges, like how to most effectively use existing data.  I particularly like that you highlight the risks of a data-driven approach, where data-mining for patterns risks displacing much richer inquiry, and I think you hit that well. 

I meant to highlight a rather different use of existing data, which is probably much closer to your own argument.  I think it is possible to use existing data in ways that aren't any more "data-driven" or "hypothesis-void" then traditional studies.  There have been many carefully designed studies to address, for instance, the diversity-stability debate in different systems. 

I agree whole-heartedly about getting the "right data."  But ultimately this is never enough.  I don't think we've ever progressed by one beautifully designed, long-term study that gets the "right data" to answer the question.  Tantalizing questions like diversity-stability are too general to be answered in one study.  Combining different sources of information in clever ways, such as exploring the evolutionary consequence of that hypothesis through phylogenetic data, consequences to patterns of spatial structure, or comparing the responses across many different systems do we get closer to an answer.  Of course I think we agree here, as you weren't saying it was necessary, not sufficient, to get the right data, but I think synthetic approaches like NCEAS can help us do this latter part better, and avoid the risk of shoehorning data inappropriately. 

I would argue that we are flooded with field data -- or at least we should be.  There's more field studies appearing every week in the journals than I can read, even in a relatively narrow subfield.  If in the last decade we learned to make certain advances by harnessing information from GenBank and satellite images, I think the next decade is moving us towards exactly the richer and more challenging data you describe through projects like DataONE and Dryad, where data is closely tied to the study it originates in and more heterogeneous in content.  Much harder data to use in a meaningful way, yes, but potentially much more informative too. 

Figuring out these challenges will require new approaches to collecting data, not just curation or analysis, and must be a cooperative effort of the whole field.

Hi Carl,
I'm curious about the utility of having a Mendeley API in R. Do you have any applications in mind? It would be great if one could reference a paper's data repository via Mendeley's API but  that seems rather difficult to implement given the non-standard way in which journals archive data in supplementary material.

Hi Karthik,

I think the most obvious application would be to help a user in computing non-trivial custom statistics across slices of Mendeley's 90 million papers  -- i.e. pull all papers by subject and produce network connectivity maps of the authors.  I'm curious what you had in mind regarding data repository?  While Mendeley archive has pdf supplements of some papers, I agree that it's an unlikely way to get anything useful.

I have been working on something similar to access the data in given papers (or query for existing data) that is deposited at the time of publication in an archive such as Dryad (datadryad.org) or TreeBASE.  Both have API's, and I have (in development) R packages which implement these in R.    Here's a basic outline of the TreeBASE project: http://www.carlboettiger.info/...

A third interesting direction in between these two is full text access through the API of Springer or PLoS.  This could allow for some interesting text-mining potential.  All projects are up on my github.  Thanks for your thoughts!

Re: I'm curious what you had in mind regarding data repository? My thought wrt to Mendeley (since it has an API under active development) was if metadata on the record could facilitate access to data in queried papers from within R (if the journals in question also have an API in place). I see a huge void with society journals (ESA and ASN in particular) since a large amount of data has already been deposited there but there is no formal API to access such content.

Although I am excited for efforts like Dryad, none of the recent ecological papers I've seen have deposited data there (or in other central repositories). I wonder if editors are encouraging authors to do so. thoughts?

Yup, integrating the APIs of Mendeley with those of journals (currently Springer and PLoS), and data repos (TreeBASE and Dryad, haven't figured out the dataONE API yet), is certainly a goal of having R packages for each of the APIs. 

Yes, the ecological journals lag considerably behind the evolution-focused ones wrt Dryad deposition; an issue Don and Marcel explored in the workshop.  Mandatory archiving for journals like Am Nat and Evolution are only just started too, so I can only hope it will get better.  Michael Whitlock and Mark McPeek at Am Nat are a testament to what can be done with a society journal.  In some ways change can be harder for non-society journal with certain publishers. Marcel has made great efforts with Ecology Letters and Dryad board, but mandatory archiving there may be a ways out.

Dear Carl

I have been hugely impressed over the past few months with the consistency and rigour of your experiment in Open Notebook Research - I really thinks it acts as an exemplar to people interested in open science.

I notice that you have assembled a set of open source components - WordPress, Mendeley, Inkscape, R, github etc. to provide a comprehensive workflow.

My question is whether your commitment to open source (which I would support) is a philosophical one? I could imagine that you could achieve the aims of reproducible research using something like Mathematica 8 (which we have freely available on an academic licence) which in one environment provides executable notebooks mixing code, text and images freely, presentation tools and archiving. They claim that they have a much greater range of symbolic and numerical algorithms than any other system including R. Wouldn't it be more convenient to work in an executable notebook than using Sweave in R for example? Or does your phylogenetic work really depend on R?

I would be interested in your thoughts.

Kind regards

Kevin

Hi Kevin,
Great question on ONS and software, you hit upon several issues.  I use open source tools more for practical reasons than philosophical ones, though I sympathize with the philosophy.  Of course free isn't the same as open source -- those practical reasons are not about cost but about performance.  Mendeley isn't open source, but their data is CC-by and available by public API, things which have a far greater impact for science.  

Mathematica notebooks are an interesting example.  The obvious reproducible research concern is the longterm viability of the company.  While getting decade-old code to run will always be an issue, a purely open-source system is probably the best hope.  But that's not my reason for using R.  Sage has attempted to implement an open source mathematica-notebook-like environment coupling symbolic reasoning (maxima) and computation (python), which could be excellent.  

The greatest advantage (and greatest headache) of R is the ease at which users can write extension packages to do almost anything.  Mathematica cannot be deployed in an high-performance computing environment, nor does it have custom phylogenetics packages, etc.  Python is almost as easy to extend and in many ways a nicer language, but it has a far smaller adoption in my community, particularly among empiricists.  I think my first advice to anyone would be to use what their community is using, until they have very good reasons to do otherwise (that don't block interoperability).  If everyone else is using Matlab, use matlab.  You can still share your scripts, etc, and there's a greater chance they will actually be useful to your community.  If there's no obvious choice though, go with the open-source alternative. 

Anyway, that's my take on it.
Carl

Nice reflection post Carl. The impact issue can be a tricky one. It can get difficult to tell if and how a specific experiment or experimental result has been used just by looking at page views. For example, people might be using a solubility measurement from our database or a specific edition of a book and never click through to the lab notebook page. When results from a notebook are re-purposed using different distribution mechanisms it becomes very difficult to track at the data point level. Focusing on "impact" or "use" might even discourage multiple dissemination channels, which I think would be counter-productive to the OS movement. Of course more general use of the entire dataset via citations and page hits can be a guide but I don't think does a good job of quantifying "impact".

Hi JC, thanks for the excellent comments. I agree that pageviews is a very misleading statistic, particularly due to the alternative distribution channels you mention. The most obvious is perhaps missing readers from rss. My counters miss lots of other things too (such as the mirrored copy on openwetware via rss) reading the current post in the "lab-notebook" home-page, or views from before I installed the counter. On the other hand a "view" isn't particularly meaningful itself. Any quantification of impact will always be hard -- I imagine testimony from peers will often be more a more useful gauge of impact than automated stats.

I think my goal here is simply to add to the pool of alternative metrics as a purely empirical test -- even if the only thing we learn by sharing page-views is that they aren't a good metric of anything. In a relative sense it may give my readers some indication of what content is more popular. Perhaps it may also surprise my readers (and myself) that things that are basically technical notes to my future self are viewed by others.

I think the situation is even better than that in the sense that the pre-print policies refer to copyright, not ideas. A researcher writing an article and using open lab notebook pages for references should be fine since the text of the article (with the purpose of integrating several experimental results and concepts) will not be identical to the text in the lab notebook. Where we ran into an issue with pre-print policies is that we also wrote the actual article on an open wiki, which is definitely a pre-print.

Thanks JC, I think the issue is not really one of copyright (as you say, the journal never owns the notebook content to any of this content) but rather of the journal refusing to publish on the grounds that the *ideas* aren't novel, as they have already been published in the notebook. Of course if the someone is only releasing the notebook after the journal accepts it, this isn't an issue, but for sharing ideas per-publication, I've often heard scientists worry that many journals would refuse publication. I was glad to see that concern is ill-founded.

Would be curious to hear more about your pre-print story -- sounds like that wouldn't have been a problem in the journals above, but ACS journals, for instance, don't seem to have similar policies.

Carl, the point about pre-prints is entirely about copyright. If ideas and results could not be assembled and "re-published", review articles would be impossible to publish in traditional journals. Essentially, a typical research article is to a collection of lab notebook pages what a review article is to a collection of research articles. Similarly, presenting a poster about your work does not count as a pre-print.

Thanks for clarifying, I think that's a great analogy, and I agree that copyright is definitely part of the preprint question and not the part of the notebook question. I just think copyright isn't the only reason a publisher could object to an early preprint, prior dissemination could be a separate issue, and could impact notebooks.

For instance, When Science, ACS, and 25 other publishers tell F1000 that they would consider poster deposition online as prior publication, and refuse to publish those results, I do not think it is because of copyright. I was glad to see that despite this position, Science is okay with the notebook concept, but wouldn't take it for granted that those other publishers wouldn't reject a work because the ideas had appeared in a notebook.

You are right that some publishers are taking a more rigid stance but I haven't heard of a case where a paper was rejected because someone did a talk or poster on it. After all that is what most researchers do at conferences. Perhaps the reason we haven't seen someone with an open notebook try to publish in an ACS journal is that someone with the mindset of keeping an Open Notebook probably also has a mindset of publishing in Open Access journals, where pre-print policies are generally excellent for the authors. So I think the concern expressed by some that keeping an open notebook is detrimental to publishing in peer-reviewed journals is not warranted.

Aha, looking closer at the RStudio markdown documentation (http://www.rstudio.org/docs/r_... reveals that 
"The Github flavored markdown extensions include:
Newlines are treated as real line breaks (rather than combining them into a single paragraph)..."

The customization page (http://www.rstudio.org/docs/au... gives the following solution:
"You may like most of the default rendering provided by RStudio however wish to add or remove selected options. The following example removes the hard_wrap HTML option:
options(rstudio.markdownToHTML =
function(inputFile, outputFile) {
require(markdown)
htmlOptions <- markdownHTMLOptions(defaults=TRUE)
htmlOptions <- htmlOptions[htmlOptions != "hard_wrap"]
markdownToHTML(inputFile, outputFile, options = htmlOptions)
}
) "I tried it and it fixed the problem. To get this behavior by default one needs only to put the above code in .Rprofile.

A note to readers: I've recently moved my lab notebook to a Jekyll-based platform, though all the posts based on Wordpress, including this one, still remain. Jekyll is faster and more flexible than Wordpress, and works very naturally with Github and markdown. As I describe in the post, most of the research activity remains Github-based, but the Jekyll notebook can be just a little more closely coupled.

Also note that knitr now recommends the extension `.Rmd` instead of `_knit_.md` for source code, and my newer work follows this format.

In principle this should be easier to extend this way, since most of the semantic content can be written in directly to the HTML. HTML5 is already more semantic then its predecessors, though it sounds like it would be best to declare the DOCTYPE and content-type as XML, which I think should allow machines to read the site as XML (and thus benefit from namespaces/ontologies for things like CiTO, etc) while rendering the same way to humans.

I wish I knew a lot more about HTML5 & XML. I found this informative: http://stackoverflow.com/quest...

Once we're in XML, we can add things like FOAF RDF to each page with the liquid {% includes %} calls, though the FOAF project recommends adding that data in a separate file with a link to it from the HTML: http://www.ldodds.com/foaf/foa.... The ideal configuration would probably pull much of this data from _config.yaml

Adding semantic data that varies from post to post (like cito citations) is more tricky. The simplest thing would be to add the citations in as XHTML lines directly into the markdown (perhaps using a little script to generate the XHTML. Of course we could write a liquid tag, but as I mention, I'm trying to keep posts as valid markdown without liquid in the entries themselves.

Anyway, that's a few thoughts for now, but looking forward to following up on this. Having the whole notebook be valid XML would have lots of advantages.

My own feeling is that reference lists should NOT be semantically marked up. Reference lists are just a denormalisation of the documents which are linked to. It should (and indeed is) possible to generate the reference list from the links. It is the links that should carry the semantics -- they are even at the right place. The reference list should be a visualisation only.

Carl, the problem with DOIs as a preservation strategy is that it depends on everyone who cites your post using the DOI. If they do the more natural thing and use the URL, it all fails.

Greycite tries to address this also. We are starting to check Web Archives; so it will be possible to get back archival copies for any URL as well as the bibliographic information. Eventually, kcite will show this information also -- a URL goes 404, any links to it will redirect to the nearest web archive.

My website is archived by the British Library. I would encourage you to do this as well. Figshare is all very well, but you need to consider two issues; first, as you say, they are not archiving in a very web friendly manner. And, secondly, NPG might get bored, and shut Figshare down with 3 days notice, as they did with Nature Preceedings.

Of course, Greycite might disappear at any point also; but, then, anyone can set up an equivalent service.

This still leaves open the question of what Google Scholar is doing to decide that you've cited something it knows about. From the examples it's clear that it processes plain text and manages to do this. It's not clear how it does so, or what formatting works best. Does it just rely on the link, if one is provided? Does it pay attention to RDFa or microdata in the list? I agree that your approach is ideal - the metadata is provided with the link in the in-text citation; and I agree with the philosophy that we aren't building the web for Google. But Scholar is clearly using the data appearing below a heading "References" to decide what is cited and what's not. So if one merely wants citations in Scholar, does RDFa help? Does following any particular styling help?
good point Philip, so what would you recommend as semantic markup for the doi/pmids?

The advantage of figshare archiving isn't the DOI so much as the fact that CLOCKSS backs them up (a geopolitically distributed network of 12 libraries around the world that archive the entire site). If figshare vanishes it triggers a CLOCKSS event that will provide all their content through that archive (the same service used to back up many journals. They have some vanished journals which are now only accessible through http://clockss.org.) From what I can tell as an ignorant outsider, systems like LOCKSS and CLOCKSS are the gold standard of internet archiving; hence my comments above.

I agree entirely about the weakness of the DOI, though the same thing can happen when someone omits the URL. Obviously that would be solved most naturally if all citations were actual web-links, but of course that's not the case. So I guess we're left with searching and disambiguating "citation styles" until we change current practice.

I will look into the British Library archiving, sounds like a great idea. Are there requirements to satisfy? Does one "apply" to be archived?
and if i want to specify that these papers are mine, or from my group it seems that the metadata would be the best way to inform that.

The British Library requires you to send in a copyright form (UK copyright law is different from US, so this is required). Archive.org requires you not to have a robots.txt file. They already archive your website.

http://web.archive.org/web/201...

As you can see, the last capture online was 2011 -- they probably have a 2012 capture, but it can take 6-12 months for them to appear online.

My question, though, is your blog, my blog, are, as you say, not "blogs", but valid academic content. Why are the libraries not archiving them better; this is, after all, their job. Perhaps we should ask?

"This will help Google Scholar identify your blog post as a academic object, and add it to your profile."

But I don't see this entry on your profile, http://scholar.google.com/cita...

One of the great things with DOIs or PMIDs is that they don't actually need semantic markup. The DOI or PMID is enough to work out what it is -- a pointer to a paper (at least for PMID; usually, but not always for a DOI). Kcite, for example, requires no semantics at all -- just the link. The semantics are at the other end in what ever they resolve to (in the case of DOIs, or PMID, actually, you need to know where to get this from implicitly which is not ideal).

If you really do want to mark things up (not a bad idea, of course), then CiTO, or the SPAR ontologies in general, seem like a good place to go. At some point I will add them to kcite, although I am yet to think of an advantage to the author from using them yet.

It's "Phillip" BTW -- I usually go by Phil though:-)

Google Scholar is probably working the same way as everything else google does -- it's using stats. If you're article looks like an article, has metadata, Google scholar will probably decide that it is.

This approach is not editor dependent, conversion to MS Word is supported by John McFarlane's excellent Pandoc package, http://johnmacfarlane.net/pand... (an external command-line utility). It sounds like you are using knitr in Sweave/LaTeX mode, which will make converting to word more difficult (Since a .Rnw file is not a valid .tex file). Knitr also supports input in Markdown, as I discuss here (".Rmd" files instead of ".Rnw" files). Pandoc can easily convert markdown to word, latex, pdf, and other formats. If you need to turn your knitr output to word, I'd recommend starting in .Rmd -> .md (via knitr) and then .md -> .docx via pandoc.
